Award.AwardTitle: A Simulation Platform to Enhance Infrastructure and Community Resilience to Extreme Heat Events

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Exposure to heat is a growing public health concern in many cities across the globe. In the US, Southwest cities have experienced increasing numbers of heat waves in the past few decades, and global climate models project significant increases in both the duration and intensity of these extreme events. Facing these challenges, very little is known about how people are exposed to heat during their day-to-day activities as they interact with urban infrastructure. To understand exposure, factors including the types of homes people live in (and whether they have and use air conditioning), their mobility choices, the quality of the infrastructure (e.g., shading, landscaping, and material choice), their work situation (e.g., air conditioned office versus outdoor worker), and their activity profiles must be considered. A systematic framework that any city can use to understand how people are exposed to heat and proactively mitigate risk is needed.

To create insight into how people are exposed to heat, this work will develop an Urban Activity Heat Simulation (UAHS) platform that will join (1) a model of residential and workplace exposure, (2) travel simulations for automobile use, public transit, and biking/walking, (3) urban infrastructure characteristics, (4) high-resolution urban climate data, and (5) a model of exposure thresholds. UAHS will be developed using Phoenix, Arizona and Los Angeles, California as case studies. Heat performance models for buildings will be combined with surveys of home and work activities to assess how people experience heat indoors. Using national and regional travel surveys combined with detailed travel models, simulations of how people move throughout cities will be developed. Downscaled climate models will be used to estimate present and future outdoor conditions in both cities. Information on infrastructure including materials, landscaping, and shading will also be used to develop estimates of outdoor exposure. Combining simulated exposures with health records will provide new insight into dangerous heat exposure profiles. The platform will be validated with in situ monitoring. UAHS will be developed with the goal of enabling any city to build upon the platform for their unique population and infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Icarus project laid the groundwork for shifting our understanding of community exposure to heat and other environmental hazards from place- to person-based, and in doing so has created a framework for assessing how to effectively deploy mitigation strategies. The project team developed the Icarus model, a meso-scale activity-based travel model of entire city regions including household and individual movements and corresponding heat exposure. Heat exposure results from both temperature as well as infrastructural conditions. The model is a major advancement in how we understand an individual’s activities and corresponding environmental exposure. Whereas previous research has largely focused on associating exposure with residence, Icarus analyzes movements over the day, associated activities, and associated urban form and temperatures. 

The Icarus model informed or was directly used in studies of heat vulnerability and mitigation, each focused on reframing how we understand human vulnerability as based on personal activities and choices. Researchers across engineering, geography, public health, and sustainability led studies on Phoenix and Los Angeles, to examine how activity choices led to heat exposure, and how heat exposure could be mitigated. This includes analyses of biking and walking routes and activity accessibility, optimal location of tree shading, and transit rerouting for heat vulnerability reduction.

The research activities supported several outreach and engagement activities. The research team formed technical advisory committees in the Phoenix and Los Angeles metro regions, and those committees provided important insights into structuring the research to inform decisionmaking. As the project developed, the City of Phoenix was actively pursuing tree shading investments. The project team directly supported the City, providing Icarus model output data. These data are being used by the city in developing a prioritization scheme for tree shading. In Los Angeles the research team deployed several new mean radiant temperature measuring techniques in two heat vulnerable neighborhoods and used the findings to support city activities towards vulnerability reduction.

Advancing heat mitigation science requires interdisciplinary teams of researchers and new methods of collaboration. The project joined engineering, meteorology, medicine, public health, and geography knowledge and techniques. In doing so a new cadre of researchers and leaders was trained. This included undergraduate students, graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, research faculty, and junior tenure track faculty. The research team spanned multiple institutions and frequently found themselves presenting to and developing new ideas in diverse domains.

The Icarus project and model are uniquely positioned to address heat mitigation challenges in U.S. cities. The model is capable of assessing the confluence of travel behavior, infrastructure, and heat exposure critical variables necessary for understanding how and where people are exposed. Deploying the model to other cities is quite feasible and can provide important insights around not just heat but other environmental hazards including cold and air pollution.
